creator: Unknown
description_en:
The main building of this square is the Pazo de Bendaña, S. XVIII with large balconies with iron railings of great artistic value. Hosted the Casino de Compostela and today is temporary headquarters of the foundation Granell.
The facade of the Pazo de Bendaña is crowned by a statue of Atlas supporting a globe weighing on his shoulders.
description_cy:
The main building of this square is the Pazo de Bendaña, S. XVIII with large balconies with iron railings of great artistic value. Hosted the Casino de Compostela and today is temporary headquarters of the foundation Granell.
The facade of the Pazo de Bendaña is crowned by a statue of Atlas supporting a globe weighing on his shoulders.

creator: Unknown
description_en: The facade of the cathedral that overlooks the Plaza de la Quintana has two doors, Puerta Real, in Baroque style, which began under the leadership of José de Vega y Verdugo José de la Peña de Toro in 1666 and completed by Domingo de Andrade in 1700, he made some great columns that cover two floors of windows, a balustrade with large pinnacles and a little building with an equestrian statue of Santiago (now defunct), very ornate with decorative fruit clusters and large-scale military trophies. Through this door accessed the kings of Spain to the cathedral, hence its name, and its threshold is the royal shield. The so-called Holy Door or Gate of Atonement is the closest to the stairs, is usually closed with a gate and opens only the jubilee years, on December 31 last year. It was one of the seven gates and was less dedicated to St. Pelayo (whose monastery is just opposite). On this door can be seen in niches image of James and his disciples Athanasius and Theodore at his side. In the lower body and both sides of the door were placed twenty-four figures of prophets and apostles (including that of the Santiago) coming from the old choir teacher Matthew Stone. Inside this door by passing a small courtyard is the true Holy Door, which enters the ambulatory of the apse of the temple.
description_cy: The facade of the cathedral that overlooks the Plaza de la Quintana has two doors, Puerta Real, in Baroque style, which began under the leadership of José de Vega y Verdugo José de la Peña de Toro in 1666 and completed by Domingo de Andrade in 1700, he made some great columns that cover two floors of windows, a balustrade with large pinnacles and a little building with an equestrian statue of Santiago (now defunct), very ornate with decorative fruit clusters and large-scale military trophies. Through this door accessed the kings of Spain to the cathedral, hence its name, and its threshold is the royal shield. The so-called Holy Door or Gate of Atonement is the closest to the stairs, is usually closed with a gate and opens only the jubilee years, on December 31 last year. It was one of the seven gates and was less dedicated to St. Pelayo (whose monastery is just opposite). On this door can be seen in niches image of James and his disciples Athanasius and Theodore at his side. In the lower body and both sides of the door were placed twenty-four figures of prophets and apostles (including that of the Santiago) coming from the old choir teacher Matthew Stone. Inside this door by passing a small courtyard is the true Holy Door, which enters the ambulatory of the apse of the temple.

creator: Unknown
description_en:
this place serves as a interspace between the facades of the Cathedral and the main entrance of the Convent of San Martino Pinario.
The north facade of the cathedral also called Azabachería, is located in the Plaza de la Inmaculada or Azabachería, draining the last part of the French, Primitivo, North and English roads through the ancient gate of Paradise.
This gate was demolished after suffering a fire 1758, some sculptural pieces that survived were placed on the facade of Platerías. The new was designed in Baroque style by Lucas Ferro Caaveiro, and finished by Domingo Lois Monteagudo, and Clement Fernandez Sarela in neoclassical style, but retained some traces of the Baroque, 1769.
At the top of the facade is a statue of Santiago del S. XVIII, with two kings in prayer: Alfonso III and Ordoño II. In the center stands the statue of Faith
description_cy:
this place serves as a interspace between the facades of the Cathedral and the main entrance of the Convent of San Martino Pinario.
The north facade of the cathedral also called Azabachería, is located in the Plaza de la Inmaculada or Azabachería, draining the last part of the French, Primitivo, North and English roads through the ancient gate of Paradise.
This gate was demolished after suffering a fire 1758, some sculptural pieces that survived were placed on the facade of Platerías. The new was designed in Baroque style by Lucas Ferro Caaveiro, and finished by Domingo Lois Monteagudo, and Clement Fernandez Sarela in neoclassical style, but retained some traces of the Baroque, 1769.
At the top of the facade is a statue of Santiago del S. XVIII, with two kings in prayer: Alfonso III and Ordoño II. In the center stands the statue of Faith

creator: Unknown
description_en:
completed in 1652, is the work of Matthew Lopez and Gonzalez de Araújo.
The front is of altarpiece structure and shows the figures of the Virgin and Child and saints Benedictine abbots. The Eternal Father chairs the triangular fronton. San Martin de Tours ends the set on top with their classical representation, on a horse and breaking his cloak to shelter a beggar.
The plan of the church has a longitudinal nave, covered with a barrel vault with false coffers. the nave opens to six side chapels that communicate with each other and have the same type of vault the nave. The cruise illuminates by a cupola in half. The choir stalls, Baroque, is the work of Matthew de Prado and the three main altarpiece, along with the Chapel of the Relief of the same temple, are by Fernando de Casas y Novoa, creating one of the finest ensembles Baroque nationally and internationally.
Currently, this building has enabled part as a museum of religious art

The plan of the church has a longitudinal nave, covered with a barrel vault with false coffers. the nave opens to six side chapels that communicate with each other and have the same type of vault the nave. The cruise illuminates by a cupola in half. The choir stalls, Baroque, is the work of Matthew de Prado and the three main altarpiece, along with the Chapel of the Relief of the same temple, are by Fernando de Casas y Novoa, creating one of the finest ensembles Baroque nationally and internationally.

creator: Unknown
description_en:
The arc of Mazarelos is one of the ancient gateways to Santiago de Compostela in the Middle Ages when it was still a walled city.
Located next to the College of Philosophy at the University of Santiago in Plaza de Mazarelos has great historical value because it is the only one of the seven gates which had the wall that still stands up.
description_cy:

creator: Gwilym Tudur
locations: [{'lat': '52.411540000000', 'lon': '-4.085111000000', 'description': {'en': 'Trefechan Bridge Protest, 2 February 1963 (1 of 7)', 'cy': 'Protest Pont Trefechan, 2 Chwefror 1963 (1 o 7)'}}]
description_en: Gwilym Tudur talking about the lack of use of the Welsh language in official matters in Wales before the Welsh Language Society was formed. He discusses road signs, the press, sending letters and also translating and interpreting.
description_cy: Gwilym Tudur yn sôn am Seisnigrwydd y byd swyddogol yng Nghymru cyn sefydlu Cymdeithas yr Iaith drwy sgwrsio am arwyddion ffordd, y wasg, anfon llythyrau a hefyd cyfieithu a chyfieithu ar y pryd.

license_additionalText_cy: Uwchlwythwyd yr eitem hon i Gasgliad y Werin trwy garedigrwydd a chaniatad Gwilym Tudur.

description_en: Gwilym Tudur talking about politics in Wales in the late 1950s and early 1960s. He pays particular attention to what was being discussed in the media - Tryweryn, the Beasleys and Saunders Lewisradio lecture.
description_cy: Gwilym Tudur yn sôn am wleidyddiaeth yng Nghymru ar ddiwedd y 1950au a dechrau'r 1960au. Mae'n rhoi sylw arbennig i'r hyn oedd yn cael ei drafod gyda'r cyfryngau - Tryweryn, teulu'r Beasleys a darlith radio Saunders Lewis.

description_en: Gwilym Tudur talks about the political agendas while he was a student at Aberystwyth University. He specifically mentions the lack of support for Plaid Cymru at the time, and the establishment of the Welsh Language Society.
description_cy: Gwilym Tudur yn sôn am y wleidyddiaeth chwerw oedd yn bodoli tra roedd yn fyfyriwr ym Mhrifysgol Aberystwyth. Mae'n sôn yn benodol am diffyg cefnogaeth tuag at Plaid Cymru ar y pryd, a sefydlu Cymdeithas yr Iaith.

creator: Gwilym Tudur
locations: [{'lat': '52.411540000000', 'lon': '-4.085111000000', 'description': {'en': 'Trefechan Bridge Protest, 2 February 1963 (7 of 7)', 'cy': 'Trefechan Bridge Protest, 2 February 1963 (7 of 7)'}}]
description_en: Gwilym Tudur talks about the unexpected response to the protest on Trefechan Bridge from both the Welsh and English medium press. He mentions the change in behaviour towards the Welsh Language Society in the press today, and also mention the other organizations that have been essential in order to gain a better status for the Welsh language.
description_cy: Gwilym Tudur yn sôn am ymateb annisgwyl y wasg i brotest Pont Trefechan mewn papurau newydd cyfrwng Cymraeg a Saesneg ar ôl meddwl bod y diwrnod wedi bod yn fethiant. Mae'n crybwyll y newid mewn ymddygiad wrth y wasg heddiw tuag at Gymdeithas yr Iaith a hefyd sôn am y sefydliadau eraill sydd wedi bod yn hanfodol er mwyn ennill gwell statws i'r iaith Gymraeg.
license_additionalText_en: Kind permission was given by Gwilym Tudur to upload this item to People's Collection
license_additionalText_cy: Uwchlwythwyd yr eitem hon i Gasgliad y Werin trwy garedigrwydd a chaniatad Gwilym Tudur.

creator: Gwilym Tudur
description_en: Gwilym Tudur talks about the efforts made to organize the Welsh Language Society's protest on 2 February 1963, and the original purpose of the day' which was to break local law by putting up posters on buildings in order to obtain summonses.
description_cy: Gwilym Tudur yn sôn am yr ymdrechion a fu i drefnu protest Cymdeithas yr Iaith ar 2 Chwefror 1963, a phwrpas gwreiddiol y diwrnod sef i dorri cyfraith leol drwy roi posteri ar adeiladau er mwyn cael gwysion.

creator: Paul White
description_en:
Notes on CANADA, Stag’s Head, Ceredigion 2014
 
 A small cottage built of mud, stone and brick and much dilapidated. It stands in a low position and perhaps if the trees in front of it hadn’t had the chance to grow so high it would have once had a good view. At present however all is dim and lowly. I wonder how long empty, it’s in a relatively good condition although there is a hole forming at the rear. Inside is very basic, nothing much of note but a fairly recent empty beer bottle. Partition walls have been taken down and all is left is one large room, upstairs also taken down, striped of beam and panel. Cottage sits beside a seldom used footpath and there was no doubt in my mind that this little gem will surely never be salvaged or lived in again.
description_cy:
Notes on CANADA, Stag’s Head, Ceredigion 2014
 
 A small cottage built of mud, stone and brick and much dilapidated. It stands in a low position and perhaps if the trees in front of it hadn’t had the chance to grow so high it would have once had a good view. At present however all is dim and lowly. I wonder how long empty, it’s in a relatively good condition although there is a hole forming at the rear. Inside is very basic, nothing much of note but a fairly recent empty beer bottle. Partition walls have been taken down and all is left is one large room, upstairs also taken down, striped of beam and panel. Cottage sits beside a seldom used footpath and there was no doubt in my mind that this little gem will surely never be salvaged or lived in again.

creator: Paul White
title_en: ABSTRACTION at Ox-Bow Lakes and the River Rheidol, Ceredigion 2003
title_cy: ABSTRACTION at Ox-Bow Lakes and the River Rheidol, Ceredigion 2003
description_en:
Notes on ABSTRACTION at Ox-Bow Lakes and the River Rheidol, Ceredigion 2003
 
 I have 'lived' with this image for almost ten years and I am still uncertain if it works as a successful abstraction. Obviously it shows some small branches and grasses in a low water stream with the refelction of the trees confusing the viewer because trees are not normally found at the bottom of a picture! But does it work as a composition? Should the small branches and grasses be central in the composition? Is it too much of an optical allusion to be taken seriously? I am still unsure if a success.
description_cy:
Notes on ABSTRACTION at Ox-Bow Lakes and the River Rheidol, Ceredigion 2003

creator: Margaret Morris
description_en:
Scientific Name:Inocybe geophylla
Fungi facts:The Lilac Fibre-cap is a common species of both deciduous and conifer woods. It forms a symbiotic association with tree roots known as a  mycorrhizal relationship where the fungal mass is  intimately associated with the tree roots. Both species benefit from this relationship; the fungus provides nutrients to the fungus and the tree provides sugars to the fungus. The fungus is deadly poisonous.
Technique:A textile assemblage
description_cy:
Scientific Name:Inocybe geophylla
Fungi facts:The Lilac Fibre-cap is a common species of both deciduous and conifer woods. It forms a symbiotic association with tree roots known as a  mycorrhizal relationship where the fungal mass is  intimately associated with the tree roots. Both species benefit from this relationship; the fungus provides nutrients to the fungus and the tree provides sugars to the fungus. The fungus is deadly poisonous.
Technique:A textile assemblage
